channel.title: Comments on: WGW37: Tesuji More Useful Than Tsumego?

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Yup. That sounds like a good plan! Looking forward to seeing your results when you start studying tesuji!
item.content:encoded: Yup. That sounds like a good plan! Looking forward to seeing your results when you start studying tesuji!

item.title: By: Eyecatcher
item.dc:creator: Eyecatcher
item.description: Very good point, but in my case, i think if i start to study mainly tesuji now i'm "building a house on sand" because i'm not yet happy enough with my L&D skills ... if i have a solid ground in that , i will focus more in tesuji.
item.content:encoded: Very good point, but in my case, i think if i start to study mainly tesuji now i’m “building a house on sand” because i’m not yet happy enough with my L&D skills … if i have a solid ground in that , i will focus more in tesuji.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Good point! Being able to tenuki when a group is already dead/alive can definitely make a huge difference. Thanks for pointing that out!
item.content:encoded: Good point! Being able to tenuki when a group is already dead/alive can definitely make a huge difference. Thanks for pointing that out!

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: No problem! To explain Sai's move, the whole idea is that prior to Sai's move, Black had a bit of territory in the center. However, Sai found the one move that could destroy Black's territory while avoiding capture. Hence it is a tesuji. Does that make sense?
item.content:encoded: No problem! To explain Sai’s move, the whole idea is that prior to Sai’s move, Black had a bit of territory in the center. However, Sai found the one move that could destroy Black’s territory while avoiding capture. Hence it is a tesuji. Does that make sense?

item.title: By: RisingStar
item.dc:creator: RisingStar
item.description: Thanks a lot Ben! I just didn't understand the point about Sai's move too well. Can you clarify? Thanks :)
item.content:encoded: Thanks a lot Ben! I just didn’t understand the point about Sai’s move too well. Can you clarify? Thanks ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Shadonra
item.dc:creator: Shadonra
item.description: There's a use for life and death besides what you pointed out - it also lets you see when you can tenuki from an enclosed group. This is less flashy than killing a group, but every tenuki you don't play costs you a stone in strength.
item.content:encoded: There’s a use for life and death besides what you pointed out – it also lets you see when you can tenuki from an enclosed group. This is less flashy than killing a group, but every tenuki you don’t play costs you a stone in strength.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Amen to that! And reading simply comes with practice. I know for me personally, it usually ends up with me getting obsessed with one tesuji like snapback. And then for a while all I'm looking for is to see if there's a snapback somewhere. Eventually it becomes a lot easier to spot and I don't have to intentionally search it out anymore. And to your point, I would agree that I would rather know that I convincingly out read my opponent than winning a game. Because in the end, in my experience, being able to read more consistently than your opponent will prove itself more valuable in the long run than simply "winning a game."
item.content:encoded:
Amen to that! And reading simply comes with practice. I know for me personally, it usually ends up with me getting obsessed with one tesuji like snapback. And then for a while all I’m looking for is to see if there’s a snapback somewhere. Eventually it becomes a lot easier to spot and I don’t have to intentionally search it out anymore.
And to your point, I would agree that I would rather know that I convincingly out read my opponent than winning a game. Because in the end, in my experience, being able to read more consistently than your opponent will prove itself more valuable in the long run than simply “winning a game.”

item.title: By: Xezlec
item.dc:creator: Xezlec
item.description: Personally, I get excited when I can read something correctly, even if it doesn't successfully catch the opponent. I'm usually terrible at reading. I once felt really good about a game I lost just because at one point I had seen a snapback a few moves ahead and it took my opponent a couple more moves to see it and adjust his play accordingly.
item.content:encoded: Personally, I get excited when I can read something correctly, even if it doesn’t successfully catch the opponent. I’m usually terrible at reading. I once felt really good about a game I lost just because at one point I had seen a snapback a few moves ahead and it took my opponent a couple more moves to see it and adjust his play accordingly.
